text: oh man it was amazing you know it was so
back to back I think it was 12 countries
and we even extended it to 60 days and
you know I was good it was I was going
so fast and there was such a few amount
of days in every country that I've only
just now kind of started to reflect on
the magnitude and kind of the impact of
it and yes I mean obviously in addition
to producing wonderful portraits it was
very eye-opening for me as well in
general how did people respond to you
when they saw you coming with your
camera well you know it was just so
amazing and one thing you know I was
working through translators which I'd
never done before and what I do is I
just kind of approach random people on
the street and I find out a little bit
about them and I've been doing this in
New York for four years and the question
was you know going to these places such
as Iraq going to places such as South
Sudan and Democratic Republic of Congo
are people going to be receptive to this
kind of thing are people going to allow
stranger to walk up and kind of find out
intimate details about their life and
you know I was amazed that you know
after traveling all over the world now
the place that I have the most
difficulty getting people to let me take
their photographs is New York City I
remember when I got back for the first
day I got rejected about five or six
times in a row and I remember it's very
new feeling I had it felt it in a long
time I think I mean essential to what
you do surely is making people feel
comfortable with this whole experience
because it's so personal taking a photo
how do you do that when you don't speak
the language right and that was the
biggest difficulty you know one of the
things that I've kind of mastered in New
York over approaching over 10,000 people
on the street and it's not just getting
someone to let you take their photo you
know after the photo I tend to ask very
personal questions like what was the
saddest moment of your life or what do
you feel most guilty about and the
entire process behind that is just
keeping things very conversational
somebody followed me one time and they
said that I used to think you were a
photographer that interviewed people but
now I just realize you're a guy that's
walking around and talking to people and
then taking their photo and that's the
key you know it's all about keeping the
interaction very conversational and when
I was traveling around the world you
know a lot of my success was dependent
upon the personality of the translator
not just their English proficiency but
their ability to just kind of be good
with people and connect with people and
make them feel comfortable Brandon we're
looking at some incredible photos you've
taken now
just come up of some kids I mean kids
are so great to take pictures of with a
the sort of same wherever you were that
kind of wide-eyed wonder or did you find
some children quite damaged by the
conflicts that they had been in or what
that experienced right you know children
I think in some especially in some of
the you know tougher places that I went
in photographed offers kind of a respite
from the I guess excuse me um I guess
from some of the you know hopelessness
we're kind of danger of an area you know
kids always seem to have a very kind of
they have their own little bubble of
childhood I remember one of the the
places that kind of exemplified this the
most as I found some children were in
Iraq and when uzd refugee camp right
after the indeed ease that fled their
homes and Sinjar and I had found a camp
where there all the parents were very
panicky and they were very worried about
their you know their relatives and I
found this group of children that were
just kind of building this car out of
cans and an empty crate and they told me
they were building a car and I just kind
of laughed it off I thought they were
using their imagination and I walked
back five minutes later and these four
children had created a actually working
automobile using nothing but bean cans
and an empty crate and wires it was
really quite amazing
being an O BL and August photographing
the Yazidis who had been ignored by so
much of the world for so long and then
became the center of such a big
international story how was that oh it
was unbelievable I mean the timing of it
was just completely coincidental you
know I had planned on going to Iraq
first but you know we were kind of
keeping an eye on security update you
know would I be able to go would I not
be able to go and if I probably had
tried to go 24 hours later I would not
have been able to go because the day I
landed was the day that the Mosul dam
got taken so I happened the four days
the five days I spent in Iraq happened
to be kind of the apex of all the the
events around there and so I was in a
very interesting position to kind of
talk to these people all these refugees
just as they were being displaced and
really to kind of depict their stories
and it was very interesting you know
when I say in my my process in New York
it's all about kind of finding out about
people's hopes and dreams and their
strongest memories
when I realize especially talking with
these refugees is that there's so many
places in the world that the present
circumstances are so overwhelming
whether that's lack of security or lack
of food where the mind doesn't really
have spear fears or compartments within
to hold aspirations or memories because
the present circumstances are so
overwhelming and when I was talking to
these refugees I realize how
inappropriate it was to ask about the
future or the past because they had
nowhere to live and they didn't know
where their family was and I just
realized that there's so many people
around the world that are just so
overwhelmed are their present
circumstances that they don't get to
have the luxury of enjoying the problems
that we have or the aspirations that we
have
